title: How to Make Bread by the Intuitive Method

steps.headline: Prepare your area and get everything ready before you start.
Ensure you have a very clean hard surface on which to knead the bread, a large bowl, a wooden spoon, warm water, your ingredients and a bowl of warm soapy water to wash your hands.

You will need some plain white bread flour, maybe some High Fibre flour, some warm clean water, some salt, possibly sugar (lo cal for diabetics) and some yeast - the small packet type that doesn't require mixing.
Place an amount of flour in a large bowl.
steps.description: The quantity and how much white and high fibre etc are up to you and your taste buds. For the first time, perhaps a kilo will be a good start.

steps.headline: Add a small packet of yeast per kilo.
steps.description: Roughly, a bit more or less will not hurt and more will probably help it to rise faster.

steps.headline: Add approximately one teaspoon and a bit of salt for each loaf you are making.
steps.description: For a kilo of flour, probably about 4 teaspoons is enough. You can't miss this stage because the salt helps the dough to rise. Don't use Lo-salt as it doesn't work. Really, it's up to you, according to your taste but you must have some.

steps.headline: Sprinkle some sugar over the top.
steps.description: It can be Lo cal if you like but it's more expensive. It's just like sprinkling sugar on cereal - according to taste. You will get the hang of it after two or three goes. Sugar, however, isn't an essential ingredient.

steps.headline: Add the butter or margarine.
steps.description: Do not use "light" because it's mainly water. Really it's up to your taste. It will help the bread to last longer but it's not absolutely necessary. Four or five knobs over the top for a kilo.

steps.headline: For a kilo you will need about one cup of boiled water to two cups of cold water to make a tepid mix.
steps.description: Make more than you need according to how the flour reacts. Use you fingers to test. When you get used to it you can forget the cups.

steps.headline: Pour two thirds of the liquid in and mix with a wooden spoon.
steps.description: Add bits of water at a time until the flour absorbs it. This is the intuitive bit because you will get good at it after a few times.

steps.headline: You can add more flour or water until it forms a lump of soft dough.
Take the dough out of the bowl and start to knead.
steps.description: Press the centre with your right hand and fold over the dough from the left with your other hand. The idea is to trap the air. (Opposite hands for left handers. )Repeat for five to ten minutes.

steps.headline: Flour the surface you are kneading on and whenever the dough gets sticky, put in more flour until it becomes elastic.
After 5 - 10 minutes (according to your strength, press the dough and, if it bounces back, it's ready.
Put the dough in the original bowl and cover with a wet tea towel.
steps.description: Let it rise until doubled in size. If in a hot country, about 45 minutes or cold country, in a warm place for up to two hours.

steps.headline: Turn out the dough and give it a thump - that's very satisfying.
steps.description: Then knead again for 1 minute only.

steps.headline: Shape into rolls or loaves (approx 3 small loaves for a kilo of flour)and place in a tin covered with the wet cloth again.
Allow to rise for half an hour or so.
Put some milk over the top with a brush or your fingers and sprinkle with poppy seeds, sesame seeds according to taste.
Put in a hot oven - not quite the highest level but almost.
steps.description: Put it near the top, if it's an old oven.

steps.headline: After 15 minutes, cover with a bit of aluminium foil and /or move around the oven depending on how brown the bread is getting.
Cook for about 30 minutes for loaves and 20 minutes for rolls.
Turn out.
steps.description: Don't burn yourself. Tap the bottom of the loaf. Hollow sound means it is done.

steps.headline: Leave to cool.
steps.description: Freeze if desired in half loaves in plastic bags so it doesn't go stale and enjoy.

steps.headline: Experiment with different combinations of flour.
It's much better than shop bread and it's intuitive, because after a few attempts, you will not need this recipe and it will all come naturally.

text: Prepare your area and get everything ready before you start.  Ensure you have a very clean hard surface on which to knead the bread, a large bowl, a wooden spoon, warm water, your ingredients and a bowl of warm soapy water to wash your hands.  You will need some plain white bread flour, maybe some High Fibre flour, some warm clean water, some salt, possibly sugar (lo cal for diabetics) and some yeast - the small packet type that doesn't require mixing.  Place an amount of flour in a large bowl. The quantity and how much white and high fibre etc are up to you and your taste buds. For the first time, perhaps a kilo will be a good start. Add a small packet of yeast per kilo. Roughly, a bit more or less will not hurt and more will probably help it to rise faster. Add approximately one teaspoon and a bit of salt for each loaf you are making. For a kilo of flour, probably about 4 teaspoons is enough. You can't miss this stage because the salt helps the dough to rise. Don't use Lo-salt as it doesn't work. Really, it's up to you, according to your taste but you must have some. Sprinkle some sugar over the top. It can be Lo cal if you like but it's more expensive. It's just like sprinkling sugar on cereal - according to taste. You will get the hang of it after two or three goes. Sugar, however, isn't an essential ingredient. Add the butter or margarine. Do not use "light" because it's mainly water. Really it's up to your taste. It will help the bread to last longer but it's not absolutely necessary. Four or five knobs over the top for a kilo. For a kilo you will need about one cup of boiled water to two cups of cold water to make a tepid mix. Make more than you need according to how the flour reacts. Use you fingers to test. When you get used to it you can forget the cups. Pour two thirds of the liquid in and mix with a wooden spoon. Add bits of water at a time until the flour absorbs it. This is the intuitive bit because you will get good at it after a few times. You can add more flour or water until it forms a lump of soft dough.  Take the dough out of the bowl and start to knead. Press the centre with your right hand and fold over the dough from the left with your other hand. The idea is to trap the air. (Opposite hands for left handers. )Repeat for five to ten minutes. Flour the surface you are kneading on and whenever the dough gets sticky, put in more flour until it becomes elastic.  After 5 - 10 minutes (according to your strength, press the dough and, if it bounces back, it's ready.  Put the dough in the original bowl and cover with a wet tea towel. Let it rise until doubled in size. If in a hot country, about 45 minutes or cold country, in a warm place for up to two hours. Turn out the dough and give it a thump - that's very satisfying. Then knead again for 1 minute only. Shape into rolls or loaves (approx 3 small loaves for a kilo of flour)and place in a tin covered with the wet cloth again.  Allow to rise for half an hour or so.  Put some milk over the top with a brush or your fingers and sprinkle with poppy seeds, sesame seeds according to taste.  Put in a hot oven - not quite the highest level but almost. Put it near the top, if it's an old oven. After 15 minutes, cover with a bit of aluminium foil and /or move around the oven depending on how brown the bread is getting.  Cook for about 30 minutes for loaves and 20 minutes for rolls.  Turn out. Don't burn yourself. Tap the bottom of the loaf. Hollow sound means it is done. Leave to cool. Freeze if desired in half loaves in plastic bags so it doesn't go stale and enjoy. Experiment with different combinations of flour.  It's much better than shop bread and it's intuitive, because after a few attempts, you will not need this recipe and it will all come naturally.
